title: David Jones in the red after further writedowns
text:
Operating profits have fallen by more than 70 per cent, from $161 million in 2015 to $64 million by 2018 and to $37 million in 2019.

Woolworths wrote down the value of David Jones by $437 million in May after a $712 million writedown in January 2018, taking total writedowns to $1.1 billion and valuing David Jones at less than $1 billion.

Woolworths chief executive Ian Moir has conceded the food and clothing retailer paid too much for David Jones at the top of the retail cycle.

"We bought it at the wrong time and we paid too much,” Mr Moir said in August.

However, Mr Moir says profits will return to growth in 2021 when a $400 million refurbishment of David Jones’ flagship Elizabeth Street store – funded half by Woolworths and half by suppliers – is completed and the retailer stops paying rent on the Market Street store sold in 2015 to fund the refurbishment.

“The fact it’s now impaired to half the level we paid for it, of course that’s disappointing, but it doesn’t mean we don’t still have a great business we can really do something with – it takes a lot of money to create what we’ve got now and we’re future proofing it for the next five to 10 years,” he said.

Woolworths has also announced plans to sell its menswear store on Melbourne's Bourke Street mall, which is expected to sell for more than $90 million, to fund the refurbishment of its flagship at 310 Bourke Street.

Mr Moir has rejected suggestions department stores are heading for extinction but said there was room in Australia for only one high-end department store.

Hence, the retailer is moving further away from its mid-market rival Myer, introducing 65 new international and Australian brands as it gradually reopens floors that have been under refurbishment for more than a year.
description: David Jones' latest $489 million loss highlights the deterioration in value since it was acquired by Woolworths for $2.1 billion in 2014.
